FieldValue.Value: End stage renal disease (ESRD): risk-adjusted standardized readmission ratio (SRR) for dialysis facility patients.

Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS). CMS ESRD measures manual for the 2017 performance period: final. Version 2.5. Baltimore (MD): Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS); 2017 Oct 11. 168 p.

Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS). Measure information form: dialysis facility compare -- standardized readmission ratio. Baltimore (MD): Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS); 2016 Oct. 11 p.
Related Health Care Delivery Measures: Use of Services
Does not apply to this measure

This measure is used to assess the risk-adjusted standardized readmission ratio (SRR) for dialysis facility patients.

The SRR is defined to be the ratio of the number of Medicare-covered index discharges from acute care hospitals that resulted in an unplanned Medicare-covered readmission to an acute care hospital within 4 to 30 days of discharge for dialysis patients treated at a particular dialysis facility, to the number of readmissions that would be expected given the discharging hospitals, the characteristics of the dialysis facility's patients and the national norm for dialysis facilities.

In 2013, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) rolled out a new approach to ensuring safe and adequate health care delivery to its patients: the CMS Quality Strategy. The CMS strategy is designed to align with the six goals of the Department of Health and Human Services' (HHS) National Quality Strategy. The CMS (2013) strategy is framed in the following way: "To improve, a broad-based and seamless reform approach is necessary to address challenges in our healthcare system—escalating costs, inadequate coverage and inefficient care of variable quality."

Dialysis patients are a population particularly affected by such issues. Relative to the general population, they experience much higher levels of mortality (de Jager et al., 2009) and morbidity (e.g., hospital readmission; Medicare Payment Advisory Commission [MedPAC], 2007). Both hospitalization and readmission rates reflect morbidity and quality of life of dialysis patients as well as medical costs. For example, in 2011 dialysis patients were admitted to the hospital twice on average and spent an average of 12 days in the hospital, accounting for approximately 38% of Medicare expenditures for end stage renal disease (ESRD) patients (U.S. Renal Data System, 2013). Furthermore, 36% of hemodialysis patients discharged from the hospital had an unplanned readmission within 30 days (U.S. Renal Data System, 2013).

In the dialysis setting, care coordination strategies, including appropriate hand-off and timely pre- and post-discharge communication among care providers, have emerged as a potentially effective means to reduce unplanned readmission among the ESRD patients. A recent study in the ESRD population found that certain post-discharge assessments and changes in treatment at the dialysis facility may be associated with a reduced risk of readmission (Chan et al., 2009). A recent multi-unit qualitative study by Reilly et al. (2013) found that a lack of care coordination between in- and outpatient dialysis units post-discharge is associated with increased readmission rates. Other articles concerning the dialysis setting (Castner, 2011; Wish, 2014) discuss the importance of dialysis facility and physician communication with the discharging hospital in order to ensure appropriate coordination of care such as reconciliation of post-discharge medications and treatment orders.

Clinical studies in the non-ESRD populations have also demonstrated that improved care coordination and discharge planning can reduce readmission rates (Dunn et al., 1994; Bostrom et al., 1996; Dudas et al., 2001; Azevedo et al., 2002; Coleman et al., 2004; Coleman et al., 2006; Balaban et al., 2008; Braun et al., 2009) or a combination of pre- and post-discharge interventions (Naylor et al., 1994; McDonald et al., 2001; Creason, 2001; Ahmed et al., 2004; Anderson et al., 2005; Jack et al., 2009; Koehler et al., 2009; Parry et al., 2009).

With the U.S. healthcare system moving toward a paradigm of shared accountability across providers from different care settings, a readmission measure that is particularly applicable to ESRD patients will not only encourage improvement in transition of care across various settings, but will also serve as a strong motivation for facilities to coordinate treatment with the discharging hospital to reduce readmission rates. Such a measure should also encourage facilities to review readmission practices and identify potential problems. Moreover, measures of the frequency of unplanned readmissions are essential for controlling escalating medical costs in that they can help facilities identify problems and potentially improve care and reduce costs.

End stage renal disease (ESRD); unplanned readmission

The expected number of hospitalizations followed by an unplanned readmission within 4 to 30 days in each facility, which is derived from a model that accounts for patient characteristics, the dialysis facility to which the patient is discharged and the discharging hospital (see the related "Denominator Inclusions/Exclusions" field)

Each facility's observed number of hospital discharges that are followed by an unplanned hospital readmission within 4 to 30 days of discharge (see the related "Numerator Inclusions/Exclusions" field)

Therapeutic Intervention

Inclusions
The expected number of hospitalizations followed by an unplanned readmission within 4 to 30 days in each facility, which is derived from a model that accounts for patient characteristics, the dialysis facility to which the patient is discharged and the discharging hospital.

The developer calculates each dialysis facility's expected number of hospitalizations followed by an unplanned readmission by fitting a model with random effects for discharging hospitals, fixed effects for facilities and regression adjustments for a set of patient-level characteristics, including measures of patient comorbidities. The developer computes the expectation for the given facility assuming readmission rates corresponding to an "average" facility with the same patient characteristics and same discharging hospitals as this facility.

All live discharges of dialysis patients from a Medicare-paid hospitalization in a calendar year are considered eligible for this measure.

Exclusions
Hospital discharges that:

  • Are not live discharges
  • Result in a patient dying within 30 days with no readmission
  • Are against medical advice
  • Include a primary diagnosis for cancer, mental health or rehabilitation
  • Occur after a patient's 12th admission in the calendar year
  • Are from a Prospective Payment System (PPS)-exempt cancer hospital
  • Result in a transfer to another hospital on the same day
  • Result in a readmission (unplanned) within 3 days of discharge
not defined yet

Inclusions
Each facility's observed number of hospital discharges that are followed by an unplanned hospital readmission within 4 to 30 days of discharge

Note: Hospitalizations are counted as events in the numerator if they were followed by an unplanned readmission that (a) occurred within 4 to 30 days of a hospital discharge and (b) was not preceded by a "planned" readmission that also occurred within 4 to 30 days of discharge. In summary, a readmission is considered "planned" under two scenarios:

  1. The patient undergoes a procedure that is always considered planned (e.g., bone marrow transplant) or has a primary diagnosis that always indicates the hospitalization is planned (e.g., maintenance chemotherapy).
  2. The patient undergoes a procedure that MAY be considered planned if it is not accompanied by an acute diagnosis. For example, a hospitalization involving a heart valve procedure accompanied by a primary diagnosis of diabetes would be considered planned, whereas a hospitalization involving a heart valve procedure accompanied by a primary diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) would be considered unplanned.

Refer to the Planned Readmission Algorithm available from the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services Web site for additional information.

Exclusions

Field.Name: Allowance for Patient or Population Factors

FieldValue.Value: not defined yet

Field.Name: Description of Allowance for Patient or Population Factors

FieldValue.Value: The risk adjustment approach used in the model for this measure was adapted from Center for Medicare & Medicaid Services' (CMS's) standardized hospitalization ratio (SHR) and CMS's Hospital-Wide Readmission (HWR) measure. The regression model used to compute a facility's "expected" number of readmissions for this measure contains many factors thought to be associated with readmission event rates. Specifically, the model adjusts for age, sex, diabetes, duration of end stage renal disease (ESRD), body mass index (BMI) at start of dialysis, past-year comorbidities, length of the index hospital stay, and the presence of a high-risk diagnosis at index discharge. In addition, the model adjusts for the effect of the discharging hospital (via random effects). Refer to the original measure documentation for additional details.
